2015 is 3rd year where Chilliwack stock is used as the brood source. In 2015 the transfer in target increased by 83K to accommodate the change of egg source for transfer out from Capilano R hatchery to Poco hatchery, and smolt source for transfer out to Westridge Terminal & Reed Pt/Ioco projects (formerly transferred out from Chilliwack R hatchery).

2015: addition of three new sites (Whonnock Cr, Stave R, and Norrish Cr). 2015: target increased from 75K to 150K. In 2011 there was a target reduction from 225K to 75K based on the assumption that angler effort would decrease following the BC Hydro dam rebuild and loss of vehicle access. However, annual Stave chum overflights have determined that there has not been a decrease in pressure as expected, so the target has been increased.

Implemented in 2014, ongoing for 2015: due to the high escapement to Tenderfoot Lk it was decided to seed Dryden Cr and Hop Ranch Cr.  Chum were likely present at both locations prior to dyking the Squamish.

Implemented in 2014, ongoing for 2015: due to the high escapement to Tenderfoot Lake it was decided to seed Dryden and Hop Ranch Creek.  Chum were likely present at both locations prior to dyking the Squamish.
Implemented in 2014, ongoing for 2015: chum fry will be placed in seapens located in the Squamish estuary prior to release.
Egg collection target set conservatively to account for variation in fecundity and BKD results.

Contingency release target to allow for surplus release in the event of higher than expected survival and disease screening. 2015: changed release site from Tenderfoot Lk to Squamish R to provide more flexibility in release sites within the Squamish R watershed (Judd Sl, Dryden Cr, Far Point Ch, Paradise Ch Low, Tenderfoot Cr, and Tenderfoot Lk).

2015: Fry rather than eyed eggs will be transferred to Capilano hatchery for rearing and eventual releases to Capilano R and tributaries, as well as to Lynn Cr, under the direction of Community Advisors.

2015: increased target by 100K. 250K is the total # of eggs transferred out if ALL alternates required (Seymour is the alternate facility used in the event MacKay Cr &/or Mossom Cr hatcheries are unable to incubate and rear pinks AND the alternate facility to Capilano R, for eventual fry release to Lynn Cr).
2015: change in stock source from Chilliwack to Cheakamus due to rockslide restricting access above Seymour canyon, thereby likely preventing returns of Chilliwack stock adults.
Alternate release site to Squamish Estuary.

Production targets set by the Enhancement subcommittee of the PST Transboundary Technical Committee. Eggs are incubated at Snettisham hatchery in Alaska, transported back for release as fry. Teslin River Tlingit First Nation feasibility project. NEF funded.

Eggs are transported to Snettisham hatchery in Alaska for incubation. Actual release target for Tahltan Lake is determined in winter of 2015/2016. Decision is based on wild adult escapement to Tahltan Lake, egg to fry survival in incubation, and a target of no more than 50% enhanced contribution to total production in Tahltan. Fry release decisions made by the Enhancement sub-committee of the Transboundary Technical Committee of the Pacific Salmon Commission.

Egg target is ~30% of available brood, up to 2M eggs. Production targets set by Enhancement subcommittee of the Transboundary Techincal Committee. Eggs are flown to Snettisham hatchery in Alaska for incubation prior to transport back for release.
This group is set aside for extended rearing on creek water at Tatsamenie following transport back from Snettisham. Contractor leads extended rearing project. Summer release of fry. NEF funded.
